review.title: A complex network approach to stylometry
review.abstract: Statistical methods have been widely employed to study the fundamental properties of language. In recent years, methods from complex and dynamical systems proved useful to create several language models. Despite the large amount of studies devoted to represent texts with physical models, only a limited number of studies have shown how the properties of the underlying physical systems can be employed to improve the performance of natural language processing tasks. In this paper, I address this problem by devising complex networks methods that are able to improve the performance of current statistical methods. Using a fuzzy classification strategy, I show that the topological properties extracted from texts complement the traditional textual description. In several cases, the performance obtained with hybrid approaches outperformed the results obtained when only traditional or networked methods were used. Because the proposed model is generic, the framework devised here could be straightforwardly used to study similar textual applications where the topology plays a pivotal role in the description of the interacting agents.

sections.heading: 6. Results and discussion
sections.text: The effectiveness of combining traditional textual characteristics and topological measurements of networks was evaluated in the context of two natural language processing tasks based on the characterization of stylistic characteristics of texts. Tasks investigated were the assignment of authorship and genre recognition problems. 13 classifiers selected for the combination of techniques were: kNN, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Random Forest (RFO) and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP). These classifiers were selected because they usually provide good accuracy rates with standard parameters [64].

sections.heading: 6.1. Authorship recognition
sections.text: The data set used here includes books written by eight authors: Arthur Conan Doyle (ACD), Bram Stoker (BRS), Charles Dickens (CHD), Thomas Hardy (THH), Pelham Grenville Wodehouse (PGW), Hector Hugh Munro (HHM) and Herman Melville (HME). To show how the topological properties of the network modeling books can be useful to improve the characterization of author styles in texts, the following combination of attributes was considered: • INT + CN: the intermittence of the stopwords was considered together with the topological measurements of the network that model the text. As stopwords, he considered all words that appeared at least once in all books of the dataset.

sections.heading: 6.2. Style identification
sections.text: In this section, I will examine whether the topological characteristics of complex networks are useful to supplement traditional textual characterization for the style identification task [66].1718The data set used was the Brown corpus [67], which comprises documents classified as either informative prose (e.g. press reportage, popular folklore and scientific manuscripts) or imaginative prose (e.g. general fiction, romance and love stories). Unlike the task of assigning authorship, the goal here is to summarize documents written using the same style independently of their authorization. Results for style identification in the Brown corpus using the hybrid technique are shown in Tables 6 and 7. Considering the INT + CN combination, the highest performance gain was 29.0% and 25.8% for the kNN methods (k = 4) and SVM methods were observed with minor improvements in the accuracy of the traditional combinations (159% were observed in the other 99).

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: In this study, I have shown that the styles of texts can be captured by measuring the topological properties of the corresponding network representation. More important than just establishing a dependence between the structure of networks and stylistic characteristics of texts, techniques were developed in this study to combine traditional and topological characteristics, which proved to be of crucial importance for improving the quality of current classification strategies. Two traditional stylistic tasks were examined: the assignment of characteristics to authorship and problems in identifying genres. In both tasks, the addition of topological characteristics led to an improvement in classification performance. The largest improvement occurred with the hybrid classifier, which uses a linear convex combination of characteristics from different textual evidence. The different nature of the quantities used to characterize texts suggests a complementary role in capturing different aspects of written texts. Since the appropriate selection of parameters for the proposed technique is anything but an automatic task, I intend to develop for each one as a future task.

Using a fuzzy classification strategy, I show that the topological properties extracted from texts complement the traditional textual description. In several cases, the performance obtained with hybrid approaches outperformed the results obtained when only traditional or networked methods were used. Because the proposed model is generic, the framework devised here could be straightforwardly used to study similar textual applications where the topology plays a pivotal role in the description of the interacting agents.
